name.text: Finding the Area of a Smaller Cone and the Slant Height of a Larger Cone from an Area Ratio

questiontext.text:
The ratio of the area of two similar cones is \(\frac{{@square_list_a@}}{{@square_list_b@}}\).

(a). Find the area of the smaller cone if the area of the bigger cone is {@c@} \(\text{m}^2\). Note: Write your answer correct to 2 decimal places.

[[input:ans1]] \(\text{m}^2\)[[validation:ans1]][[feedback:prt1]]

(b). If the slanting height of the smaller cone is {@d@} m find the slanting height of the larger cone.Note: Write your answer correct to 2 decimal places.

[[input:ans2]] m[[validation:ans2]][[feedback:prt2]]

generalfeedback.text:
Worked solution

\(\begin{align}\text{(a).Area of the smaller cone} = \frac{{@square_list_a@} \times {@c@}}{{@square_list_b@}}\\={@small_cone@}\\={@ta@}\end{align}\)

\(\begin{align}\text{(b).Slant height of the larger cone} = \frac{{@square_list_b@} \times {@d@}}{{@square_list_a@}}\\={@ta1@}\end{align}\)

prtcorrect.text: Correct answer, well done.

prtpartiallycorrect.text: Your answer is partially correct.

prtincorrect.text: Incorrect answer.

node.description: : Reversing the ratio of the areas

truefeedback.text: It looks like you may have reversed the ratio of the areas. The ratio is given as smaller to larger, so the smaller cone’s area should be the corresponding fraction of the larger cone’s area. Make sure the ratio you use matches which cone you are finding the area for.

node.description: Treating the area ratio as a linear ratio

truefeedback.text: It looks like you may have treated the given area ratio as if it applied directly to lengths. Remember, the ratio given compares the areas of the cones, not their linear dimensions. Since the areas are already in the ratio \(\frac{{@square_list_a@}}{{@square_list_b@}}\), you can use this ratio directly to find the smaller area from the larger one.

node.description: Using the area ratio directly for slanting height

truefeedback.text: It looks like you may have used the area ratio directly to find the slanting height. Remember, slanting height is a linear measurement, so you must first find the linear scale factor by taking the square root of the area ratio before applying it.

It looks like you may have used the scale factor in the wrong direction. Because you are finding the slanting height of the larger cone, the linear scale factor should increase the measurement from the smaller cone. Make sure the ratio you use reflects this enlargement.

qtest.description: Test case assuming the teacher's input gets full marks.
